newsitem.title: FRANCE: Algeria says 42 parties running in poll.
newsitem.headline: Algeria says 42 parties running in poll.

text.p: Forty-two parties will run for Algeria's 380-seat National Assembly with the main political forces fielding their leaders in Algiers constituency, the poll's big prize with 24 seats, officials said on Wednesday.

Officials expect about 4,000 candidates to run for seats in the June 5 parliamentary elections in the North African country where more than five years of violence followed the cancellation of the last general election.

About 60,000 people have been killed in violence pitting Moslem guerrillas against government forces. The latest deaths -- 93 in a massacre earlier this week -- stunned the country and overshadowed preparations for the poll.
The government extended to Thursday a Monday deadline for candidates to complete individual application forms when the final number will be officially known, officials said.

Only three parties -- the former ruling National Liberation Front, legal Islamist Nahda and National Democratic Rally (RND) -- fielded condidates in all Algeria's 48 provinces and among Algerian expatriates in Europe and other countries, said the officials, contacted by telephone.

Several ministers, including Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyahia, are standing in the one-stage poll under the RND flag. The RND, grouping President Liamine Zeroual's supporters, held its founding congress early this month.
Finance Minister Abdelkrim Harchaoui runs as RND candidate in the eastern province of Setif which will have 16 seats, the largest constituency after Algiers.
Foreign Minister Ahmed Attaf is also an RND candidate in Ain Defla, southwest of Algiers.

Ouyahia will defend the RND flag in Algiers against hawkish anti-Islamist Democracy and Culture Rally opposition chief Said Saadi, main secular opposition Socialist Forces Front (FFS) leader Seddik Debaili and other opposition politicians.
Algeria has been without an elected parliament since early 1992 when the authorities cancelled a general election in which the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) had taken a commanding lead.
The outlawed FIS has called on Algerians to boycott the poll saying it would be neither fair nor free.

Former Algerian president Ahmed Ben Bella's Movement for Democracy in Algeria (MDA) party said it would stay away from the vote, saying the country needed a peaceful solution to end bloodshed through dialogue between opposition and the government before polls were held.
The radical anti-Islamist Ettahaddi party, which says Algeria needs to wipe out all Islamist groups, including legal ones, will also boycott the poll.
